abstract.p: Objective: In an effort to combat the mental health disparities that exist among Latinos, the current study aimed to add to our knowledge related to culturally appropriate assessments for Latino children presenting with ADHD. Method: As part of a larger study, a community sample of 68 Spanish-speaking, Latino parents completed the Spanish translation of the Disruptive Behavior Disorders Rating Scale (DBD-S), a commonly used, parent-report measure of ADHD. Results: Results suggest that although both the Inattentive and Hyperactive/Impulsive subscales of the DBD-S are psychometrically sound, the Hyperactive/Impulsive subscale may not be culturally appropriate with some Latino families, particularly those who are less acculturated. This was further supported by preliminary evidence suggesting that this subscale also was not diagnostically useful with the current, community sample. Conclusion: The potential problems associated with the overemphasis on symptomatology when working with Latino families, the importance of examining functional impairment as part of a culturally appropriate assessment, and the need to replicate the current findings with a clinical sample are discussed.

body.p: It is estimated that approximately one third of the children in the United States suffer from a mental health disorder, with ADHD identified as one of the most common mental health disorders in children (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2000; Bird et al., 2001; Duchnowski, Kutash, & Friedman, 2002). Unfortunately, less than 50% of these children receive professional services of any kind (Kataoka, Zhang, & Wells, 2002), with this percentage sharply rising for Latino and other ethnic minority youth despite their greater risk for developing mental health problems (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2000; Kataoka et al., 2002; Yeh, McCabe, Hough, Dupuis, & Hazen, 2003). To combat the disparity between need and utilization of services among ethnic minority families, researchers have begun to emphasize the importance of developing culturally appropriate mental health assessments and interventions (Callejas, Nesman, Mowery, & Gamache, 2006; Flores et al., 2002). Unfortunately, progress toward this goal cannot be accomplished without reliable, valid, and culturally appropriate assessment tools. Thus, the goal of the current study was to examine the psychometric and cultural properties, as well as the diagnostic utility of a Spanish translation of a commonly used Parent-Rating Scale for ADHD with a community sample of Spanish-speaking, Latino parents.

sec.title: Mental Health Disparities
sec.p: Understanding the current mental health disparities that exist among Latinos is a public health concern as they are one of the fastest growing ethnic minority groups in the United States and are estimated to compromise approximately one fifth of the children in our country by the middle of this century (Ramirez & de la Cruz, 2003; Day, 2010). This is of particular importance for the field of clinical child psychology as research suggests that Latino youth are at an increased risk for developing childhood externalizing disorders, such as ADHD (Canino et al., 2004; Dominguez de Ramirez & Shapiro, 2005; U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2001; Yeh et al., 2003). Despite this increased risk, they are less likely than any other ethnic minority group to be treated in clinical or school-based settings (Garland et al., 2005; Hough et al., 2002; Kataoka et al., 2002; Rowland et al., 2002; Woods et al., 2005), and their parents are less likely than Caucasian parents to pursue and successfully complete psychosocial and pharmacological interventions for them (Kazdin, Holland, & Crowley, 1997; Leslie et al., 2003; McCabe et al., 1999; McMiller & Weisz, 1996; Safer & Malever, 2000).

Both practical and cultural factors have been identified as contributing to this discrepancy between need and utilization of mental health services by Latino families. Unfortunately, common practical barriers experienced by many of these families, such as lack of health insurance, unreliable transportation, and inability to pay for child care, are likely the direct result of limited parental education and poverty, which are far too common in ethnic minority families in this country (Alegría et al., 2007; Flores, Abreu, Olivar, & Kastner, 1998; U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2001; Vega & Lopez, 2001). Although some barriers to care may not be specific to Latinos, but rather shared by families from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, several additional barriers are specific to Latino families, including immigration status, command of the English language, lack of knowledge about and distrust of the mental health field, and lack of bilingual/bicultural providers (Callejas et al., 2006; Flores et al., 2002; Peifer, Hu, & Vega, 2000).

Beyond these initial cultural barriers, research also suggests that culture likely influences Latino parental beliefs about the etiology of mental illness, as well as schemas for mental health disorders, such as ADHD. Specifically, initial findings suggest that Latino parents are less likely to perceive biopsychosocial (e.g., medical or physical) factors as causes of their children’s mental health disorders, which also may explain their underutilization of professional mental health services (Yeh et al., 2005; Yeh, Hough, McCabe, Lau, & Garland, 2004). It also has been suggested that the development of Latino parental schemas for ADHD are based on the child’s functioning (e.g., poor academic performance, peer problems), rather than the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th ed., text rev.; DSM-IV-TR; APA, 2000) symptoms (Arcia & Fernández, 1998; Bauermeister et al., 2005). In sum, these findings suggest that Latino parents may not recognize ADHD symptoms in their children, and if they do, they may not perceive them as having a biopsychosocial origin, which may result in them not identifying the behaviors as problematic or in need of mental health assessment and treatment.

sec.title: Assessment of ADHD
sec.p: To meet DSM-IV-TR criteria for ADHD, a child must be displaying a developmentally inappropriate level of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity and must be experiencing impairment due to these symptoms (APA, 2000). Although rarely used outside of university-based clinics, comprehensive ADHD assessments use a multimethod, multi-informant approach, which emphasizes the importance of gathering information using several methods (i.e., interviews, measures, and observations) and several informants (i.e., parents and teachers; Pelham, 2002; Pelham, Fabiano, & Massetti, 2005). Using this approach allows for a thorough diagnostic assessment of ADHD symptomatology and other commonly occurring disorders, as well as an analysis of functional impairment, which is crucial for effective treatment planning. Unfortunately, most children in the United States do not receive a comprehensive assessment when they present with ADHD symptoms. The “typical” ADHD assessment involves the completion of an ADHD symptom checklist by the mother in the pediatrician’s office (Pelham et al., 2005).

Interestingly, when examining evidence-based assessment of ADHD, Pelham et al. (2005) concluded that the “diagnostic phase of assessment should be completed with minimal time and expense” (pp. 449) given that the diagnostic label does not have treatment utility. Specifically, they argued that interviews do not provide incremental validity beyond the use of Parent- and Teacher-Rating Scales, which can be completed and scored quickly; however, they also emphasized that a diagnostic assessment is not sufficient for treatment planning and monitoring. Thus, Pelham and colleagues argued that in addition to establishing the presence and severity of DSM-IV-TR symptoms, an evidence-based ADHD assessment should include assessment of functional impairments, identification of specific behaviors to be targeted in treatment, and identification of any contributing environmental factors. Others also have argued that our current approach to clinical assessments has resulted in an overemphasis on symptoms with a neglect of functional problems or impairments (Gordon et al., 2006; Raggi & Chronis, 2006). In addition, even though ADHD symptoms create the functional problems observed in children with ADHD, research indicates that the assessment of symptoms and functional problems are not highly correlated (Gordon et al., 2006; Raggi & Chronis, 2006; Smith, Barkley, & Shapiro, 2006), which suggests the importance of examining both when completing an assessment.

sec.title: Culturally Appropriate ADHD Assessments
sec.p: This overreliance on identification of ADHD symptoms may be particularly problematic when assessing ethnic minority children, such as Latinos. Although limited, research suggests that shifting our focus to the identification of functional impairments commonly associated with ADHD (e.g., difficulty getting along with others or performing poorly at school) may serve as a more culturally appropriate way of assessing for ADHD given that impairment, rather than symptoms, may be a more universally shared construct across cultures (Arcia & Fernández, 1998; Bauermeister et al., 2005). Unfortunately, research has not moved in this direction yet. Current recommendations emphasize the importance of conducting a linguistically and culturally appropriate assessment. Thus, to date, the focus of research has been on establishing the psychometric and cultural properties of Spanish translations of assessment measures that were designed for use with Caucasian families.

Specifically, several global measures of child psychopathology (e.g., the Child Behavior Checklist/6-18 [CBCL]; Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001; Spanish translation by Rubio-Stipec, Bird, Canino, & Gould, 1990), as well as disorder-specific measures (e.g., the Conners-3; Conners, 2008) and diagnostic interviews (e.g., the National Institute of Mental Health Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children–Version IV; Shaffer, Fisher, Lucus, Dulcan, & Schwab-Stone, 2000; Spanish translation by Bravo et al., 2001) have been translated to Spanish and examined to determine their psychometric properties. Research suggests that these translated measures demonstrate good reliability and validity. Importantly, this line of research has been extended to include specific measures of functional impairment in addition to symptoms, as well as to examine cultural properties of the measures in addition to psychometric properties. Specifically, findings suggest that translated measures of parenting stress (Parenting Stress Index–Short Form; Abidin, 1995; Spanish translation by Solis & Abidin, 1991), efficacy (Parental Sense of Competence Scale; as cited in Johnston & Mash, 1989; Spanish translation by Haack, Gerdes, Schneider, & Hurtado, 2011), and behavior (Alabama Parenting Questionnaire; Shelton, Frick, & Wootton, 1996; Spanish translation by Haack, Gerdes, Schneider, et al., 2011) as well as family chaos (Confusion Hubbub and Order Scale; Matheny, Wachs, Ludwig, & Phillips, 1995; Spanish translation by Haack, Gerdes, Schneider, et al., 2011) demonstrate psychometric properties similar to the English versions. Recently, many of these measures also have been shown to demonstrate cultural validity in that they appropriately correlate with theoretically related measures of acculturation.

Beyond establishing the psychometric and cultural properties of commonly used assessment measures, additional measures assessing cultural factors also are recommended (Padilla & Medina, 2001; Rothe, 2005). This recommendation is based on research showing that relative to Caucasian parents, Latinos are more likely to hold collectivist values, spiritual beliefs about the etiology of mental health problems, and an external locus of control (Lujan & Campbell, 2006; Skinner, Correa, Skinner, & Bailey, 2001; Yeh et al., 2004, 2005), which increase the likelihood that a parent may be more accepting of their child’s difficult behaviors, as well as less likely to perceive them as problematic or in need of mental health treatment (Arcia & Fernández, 2003a, 2003b; Rothe, 2005; Schmitz & Velez, 2003). Thus, as part of a comprehensive assessment, it may be helpful to have Latino parents complete a measure of acculturation to determine how acculturated the family is to Anglo culture versus Latino culture (e.g., Acculturation Rating Scale for Mexican Americans [ARSMA]-II; Cuéllar, Arnold, & Maldonado, 1995), as well as a measure of core Latino values (e.g., Mexican American Cultural Values Scale for Adolescents and Adults; Knight et al., 2009).

sec.title: Psychometric Properties, Cultural Properties, and Diagnostic Utility
sec.p: As previously mentioned, the first step toward providing a linguistically appropriate assessment involves translating the measures of interest and establishing their psychometric properties. Although there are many ways to determine if a measure is psychometrically sound, the most common methods include establishing the measure’s reliability or internal consistency as determined by a Cronbach’s alpha of .70 or higher, as well as construct validity, which is typically established by examining convergent and discriminant validity (i.e., examining how well the measure is correlated with measures assessing a similar construct and how well it is uncorrelated with measures assessing a different construct; Cortina, 1993; Cronbach, 1951; Cronbach & Meehl, 1955; Messick, 1995; Sattler, 2001).

Although determining the psychometric properties of a translated measure is essential, establishing the measure’s cultural properties also is necessary to provide a culturally appropriate assessment. Factors of acculturation and cultural values (e.g., familism) have been shown to affect parental and family functioning in Latinos, as well as parental perceptions related to normal child development and the origin and identification of mental health problems in their children (Bornstein & Cote, 2006; Miranda, Bilot, Peluso, Berman, & Van Meek, 2006; Miranda, Estrada, & Firpo-Jimenez, 2000; Rodriguez, Mira, Paez, & Myers, 2007). Thus, it is possible that a psychometrically sound measure may not be entirely appropriate for use with certain ethnic minority groups if cultural factors result in the measure no longer being culturally valid. Unfortunately, there is no well-established method for examining the cultural properties of translated measures. However, theoretical research suggests that ethnicity should not be examined as a categorical variable (Comstock, Castillo, & Lindsay, 2004), and recent research has provided evidence for the cultural properties of translated measures by examining their relation with a measure of acculturation, a dimensional variable assessing one’s cultural values and behaviors (Haack, Gerdes, Schneider, et al., 2011).

Finally, when examining measures that were designed to be used when conducting clinical assessments, determining the translated measure’s diagnostic utility is important to examine. This is typically accomplished by calculating the positive predictive power (PPP) and negative predictive power (NPP) of the measure, which examine the probability of the disorder given the presence or absence of a symptom, respectively (Landau, Milich, & Widiger, 1991). Several studies with predominately Caucasian samples (all of whom were English speakers) have provided evidence for the diagnostic utility of the DSM-IV-TR ADHD symptoms in predicting the presence of ADHD (community sample, Owens & Hoza, 2003; clinical sample, Frick et al., 1994). However, as discussed previously, it is quite possible that a measure demonstrating diagnostic utility in one population may not be entirely appropriate for diagnosing children of different ethnic and cultural backgrounds.

sec.title: Current Study
sec.p: Thus, in an effort to lessen the mental health disparities that exist for Latino families in our country and to provide evidence-based, culturally appropriate assessments of childhood ADHD, the goal of the current study was to determine the psychometric and cultural properties, as well as the diagnostic utility of the Spanish translation of the Parent Disruptive Behavior Disorders Rating Scale (DBD-S), which is a commonly used measure of DSM-IV-TR symptoms of ADHD and related externalizing disorders. To establish the psychometric properties of the DBD-S, reliability and validity of the ADHD subscales (i.e., Inattentive and Hyperactive-Impulsive Symptom subscales as well as the Total ADHD subscale) were examined. It was predicted that the ADHD subscales of the DBD-S would demonstrate good reliability, with Cronbach’s alpha values ≥.70. It was also predicted that the ADHD subscales would demonstrate good convergent validity by correlating with other measures of behavioral problems (i.e., the Broadband Externalizing Scale of the Spanish CBCL/6-18 [CBCL-S; Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001; Spanish translation by Rubio-Stipec et al., 1990] and the Inattention and Hyperactivity/Impulsivity subscales of the Spanish Conners-3 [Conners, 2008]). Finally, it was predicted that the ADHD subscales would demonstrate good concurrent validity by appropriately distinguishing problem children from nonproblem children as measured by the Broadband Externalizing Scale of the CBCL-S and the Inattention and Hyperactivity/Impulsivity subscales of the Spanish Conners-3.

Consistent with theoretical research arguing against measuring ethnicity categorically and previous research methodology examining ethnicity dimensionally based on an individual’s values and behaviors (Comstock et al., 2004; Haack, Gerdes, Schneider, et al., 2011), the cultural properties of the DBD-S were determined by comparing the relationship between the ADHD subscales and a measure of acculturation (i.e., Mexican and Anglo orientation on the ARSMA-II) to the relationship between acculturation and measures of functional impairment (i.e., Learning Problems, Aggression Problems, Executive Functioning Problems, and Peer Problems subscales on the Spanish Conners-3). Subscales were considered culturally unbiased if no relationship emerged between the subscales and measures of acculturation, suggesting that one’s cultural values and behaviors were not related to their ratings of symptomatology or functional impairment. It was predicted that measures of functional impairment would be culturally unbiased, whereas measures of ADHD symptomatology would be related to measures of acculturation, specifically Anglo orientation, suggesting potential cultural bias. Finally, to examine the diagnostic utility of the DBD-S with Spanish-speaking, Latino parents, the predictive power of individual ADHD symptoms was examined. It was predicted that the inattentive and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms would not yield high diagnostic utility.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants included 68 Spanish-speaking, Latino parents who were recruited as part of a larger study examining the psychometric and cultural properties of several Spanish-language assessment measures. Parents had a mean age of 33.69 years (SD = 5.78) and were predominately female (85.30%) and of Mexican descent (85.30%). To be included in the study, parents had to have at least one child between the ages of 6 and 12 years. The majority of children were male (60.30%) and had a mean age of 7.96 years (SD = 2.01). Examination of demographic information revealed that participants were generally representative of the Latino population in that geographic region. See Table 1 for more details.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Recruitment took place at elementary schools in a suburb of a moderate-sized midwestern city. Culturally appropriate recruitment strategies based on the National Institutes of Health (2002) recommendations were developed and used (for a more detailed explanation of recruitment, see Haack, Gerdes, Cruz, & Schneider, 2011). Briefly, participants were initially contacted with a parent letter distributed by the school. Along with the letter describing the study, parents received a postcard indicating times that the research team would be available at the school. Parents were asked to return the postcard with their contact information if they were interested in participating. In addition, Latino parents from three of the four schools received automated phone calls from the school describing the project and encouraging interested parents to call the school. Bilingual and bicultural research assistants also attended family-oriented events at the elementary schools to provide additional information about the study, as research has shown that face-to-face contact is especially important when recruiting ethnically diverse populations (Roosa et al., 2008). Participation took approximately 1 hr and occurred at the elementary schools, either following the school day or at school-sponsored events. Due to parental schedules, several parents needed to leave the session prior to completing their packets. These parents either completed the remainder of their packets over the phone with a bilingual research assistant or returned their packet via mail. All analyses were run with and without data from these parents, and the pattern of findings remained the same. Following consent, parents independently completed the measures and were encouraged to ask bilingual research assistants any questions that arose. Parents received a US$10 gift card for their participation.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Measures of interest for the current study included DBD-S (Pelham, Gnagy, Greenslade, & Milich, 1992), CBCL/6-18 (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001; Spanish translation by Rubio-Stipec et al., 1990), Conners 3–Parent Short (Conners, 2008), and ARSMA-II (Cuellar et al., 1995).

sec.title: DBD-S
sec.p: The DBD-S (Pelham et al., 1992) is a 42-item parent-report measure that examines symptoms of disruptive behavior disorders, including ADHD, with symptoms measured on a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 0 to 3. Symptoms are considered to be clinically present if they receive a rating of 2 (pretty much) or 3 (very much). The English version of the Disruptive Behavior Disorders Rating Scale (DBD) has demonstrated good psychometric properties. Internal consistency greater than .70 has been reported (Gerdes & Hoza, 2006), and the measure has been shown to have diagnostic utility in predicting the presence of ADHD in a community sample (Owens & Hoza, 2003). Consistent with recommendations by Brislin (Brislin, 1970; Brislin, Lonner, & Thorndike, 1973), the Spanish translation of this measure was forward and back translated by two different bilingual individuals. Initial modifications were made after comparisons between the original English and back-translated English were completed, and additional modifications were made after the Spanish translation was reviewed by a third bilingual mental health professional.

sec.title: CBCL-S
sec.p: The CBCL-S (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001; Spanish translation by Rubio-Stipec et al., 1990) is a 112-item parent-report measure that assesses a wide variety of childhood problems, including both internalizing and externalizing problems. Items are scored on a 3-point scale; 0 indicates the item is not true, 1 indicates it is somewhat or sometimes true, and 2 indicates it is very true or often true. The measure provides broadband scores for internalizing, externalizing, and total problems, as well as more specific syndrome scales; the broadband externalizing score is the only one of interest in the current study. Extensive research with the English version has indicated strong psychometric properties (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001). The CBCL-S has also demonstrated good psychometric properties; the Broadband Internalizing and Externalizing Scales have good internal consistency, with alphas ranging from .89 to .94, and good concurrent validity (Rubio-Stipec et al., 1990).

sec.title: Spanish Conners 3–Parent Short
sec.p: The Spanish Conners-3 (Conners, 2008) is a 23-item parent-report measure that examines ADHD symptoms (Inattention and Hyperactivity/Impulsivity Scales) and related problems (Learning Problems, Executive Functioning, Aggression, and Peer Relations Scales). Items are measured on a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 0 (not true at all) to 4 (very much true). Higher scores indicate more difficulty in that domain. Conners (2008) reported good internal consistency (Cronbach’s α = .84) for the Spanish version; strong convergent and discriminate validity also have been reported for the English version.

sec.title: ARSMA-II
sec.p: The ARSMA-II (Cuellar et al., 1995) is a 30-item, bidimensional measure of acculturation that measures an individual’s Mexican orientation (Mexican Orientation subscale [MOS]) and Anglo orientation (Anglo Orientation subscale [AOS]). The measure assesses (a) language use and preference, (b) ethnic identity and classification, and (c) ethnic interaction on a 5-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely often or almost always). Cuellar et al. (1995) reported coefficient alphas of .83 for the AOS and .88 for the MOS. Good construct validity also has been demonstrated by the measure’s ability to differentiate five generational levels of Mexicans and Mexican Americans (Cuellar et al., 1995).

sec.title: Psychometric Properties
sec.p: To establish the psychometric properties of the DBD-S, reliability and validity were examined. Specifically, the internal consistency of the DBD-S was determined by computing Cronbach’s α values for the ADHD subscales. As predicted, the ADHD subscales (i.e., Inattentive, Hyperactive-Impulsive, and Total ADHD) all revealed good internal consistencies with alpha values ≥.83 (see Table 2). To determine convergent validity, correlations between the ADHD subscales and other broad measures of behavioral problems (i.e., the Broadband Externalizing Scale of the CBCL-S and the Inattention and Hyperactivity/Impulsivity subscales from the Spanish Conners-3) were examined. As seen in Table 3, all three ADHD subscales revealed significant correlations with all other measures of behavioral problems, ranging from .29 to .63.

sec.p: Finally, to investigate the concurrent validity, binary logistic regressions examining the likelihood of the ADHD subscales in distinguishing problem from nonproblem children as measured by borderline or clinical elevations on the Broadband Externalizing Scale of the CBCL-S (i.e., T-scores of 59 or higher) and Spanish Conners-3 (i.e., T-scores of 65 or higher on either Inattention or Hyperactivity/Impulsivity subscales) were used. As shown in Table 4, results of the models suggest that the ADHD subscales reliably distinguished between children displaying clinically significant externalizing problems. Examination of Cox and Snell and Nagelkerke R2 values demonstrates that between 10% and 31% of the variability in the presence of externalizing problems was explained by parental ratings on the ADHD subscales of the DBD-S, and examination of odds ratios indicate that parents who reported higher severity of symptomatology on the ADHD subscales were between 1.42 and 31.05 times more likely to report their child as clinically elevated for externalizing problems on the CBCL-S or Spanish Conners-3.

sec.title: Cultural Properties
sec.p: To determine the cultural properties of the DBD-S in relation to the cultural properties of functional impairment scales, correlations examining the relationship between parental acculturation and the ADHD subscales of the DBD-S as well as the functional impairment subscales of the Spanish Conners-3 were conducted (see Table 5). Parental acculturation was significantly and positively related to the Hyperactive-Impulsive Symptom subscale of the DBD-S (r = .24), such that higher Anglo orientation was related to higher ratings of hyperactivity-impulsivity. In addition, a trend toward significance for the Total ADHD subscale was observed (r = .20), such that higher Anglo orientation was marginally related to higher ratings of total ADHD symptomatology. Interestingly, parental acculturation was not significantly related to the Inattentive Symptom subscale. Similarly, no significant relationships between parental acculturation and ratings of functional impairment on the Spanish Conners-3 (e.g., learning problems, aggression problems, executive functioning problems, peer problems) were revealed.

sec.title: Diagnostic Utility
sec.p: Finally, to examine the diagnostic utility of the DBD-S, diagnostic criteria had to be established before computing the analyses related to PPP and NPP. A child was considered to have a diagnosis of ADHD if he or she met criteria on two of three clinical measures (i.e., the DBD-S, CBCL-S, or Spanish Conners-3). Criteria were met on the DBD-S if the parent endorsed six or more inattentive and/or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms with a rating of 2 or 3, indicating a moderate or severe problem. On the CBCL-S, criteria were met if the profile indicated a borderline or clinical elevation on the Externalizing Scale (i.e., a T-score ≥59), and on the Spanish Conners-3, criteria were met if the profile indicated clinical elevations (i.e., a T-score ≥65) on either the Inattention or Hyperactivity/Impulsivity subscales. Using this method, six children (8.8%) met criteria for ADHD, which represents a similar prevalence as would be estimated in the larger population (APA, 2000).

Using the above criteria, the diagnostic utility of the DSM-IV-TR ADHD symptoms was calculated using corrected PPP (cPPP) and corrected NPP (cNPP) statistics for parent-reported symptoms on the DBD-S. The formulas for these calculations are equivalent to the formulas used in Frick et al. (1994). The PPP statistic indicates the conditional probability that the disorder is present if the symptom is present, whereas the NPP statistic indicates the conditional probability that the disorder is absent if the symptom is absent. Both are corrected to control for the base rates of each symptom, which enables researchers to compare symptoms of different base rates (Frick et al., 1994).

As seen in Table 6, results indicate that, in general, the inattentive symptoms on the DBD-S had moderately strong diagnostic utility for predicting the presence of the disorder (M = .51, SD = 0.22). Two inattentive symptoms had particularly high diagnostic utility. Specifically, “often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly” and “often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities” had cPPP values of 0.73 and 1.00, respectively. In general, the inattentive symptoms also provided moderately strong diagnostic utility in predicting the absence of the disorder (M = .49, SD = 0.16). Specifically, four symptoms (i.e., “often is easily distracted,” “often fails to give close attention to details,” “often has difficulty sustaining attention,” and “often loses things”) had cNPP values greater than 0.60.

sec.p: In contrast, results indicate that the hyperactive-impulsive symptoms on the DBD-S had much lower diagnostic utility than the inattentive symptoms in predicting the presence of the disorder (M = .31, SD = 0.17), as no hyperactive or impulsive symptoms had cPPP values greater than 0.50 as no hyperactive or impulsive symptoms had cPPP values greater than 0.50 (see Table 6). Similarly, the overall diagnostic utility of the hyperactive-impulsive symptoms in predicting the absence of the disorder was lower than the inattentive symptoms (M = .34, SD = 0.17). The only exception is “often has difficulty awaiting turn,” which had a cNPP value of 0.62.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The existence of mental health disparities among Latinos is well documented, and recommendations related to providing culturally appropriate assessments and interventions have been set forth in an effort to combat these disparities (Callejas et al., 2006; Flores et al., 2002; Garland et al., 2005; Hough et al., 2002; Kataoka et al., 2002; Rowland et al., 2002; Woods et al., 2005). To date, much of the assessment research in this area has focused on translating existing assessment measures and examining their psychometric properties (e.g., Bravo et al., 2001; Conners, 2008; Rubio-Stipec et al., 1990). Although this is a good starting point, it may not be enough, especially in light of research documenting cultural differences in parental schemas for childhood mental health disorders, such as ADHD. Specifically, initial research suggests that the field’s overemphasis on DSM-IV-TR symptomatology may be particularly problematic when completing ADHD assessments with Latino families (Arcia & Fernández, 1998; Bauermeister et al., 2005). Thus, the goal of the current study was to examine not only the psychometric properties of the DBD-S, a commonly used parent-report measure of ADHD symptoms but also the cultural properties and diagnostic utility of the measure in a community sample of Spanish-speaking, Latino parents. Results suggest that although both ADHD subscales of the DBD-S are psychometrically sound (i.e., they demonstrated good reliability and construct validity), the Hyperactive-Impulsive subscale may not be culturally appropriate with some Latino families, particularly those who are less acculturated. This was further supported by preliminary evidence suggesting that this subscale also was not diagnostically useful with the current, community sample.

sec.title: Psychometric Properties
sec.p: As predicted, examination of the psychometric properties of the DBD-S suggested that the ADHD subscales (i.e., Inattentive, Hyperactive-Impulsive, and Total ADHD) demonstrated good reliability, as well as convergent and concurrent validity. Specifically, all subscales had Cronbach’s alpha levels in the .80s to .90s, and all subscales were significantly correlated with the Externalizing Scale of the CBCL-S, as well as the ADHD subscales of the Spanish Conners-3, measures assessing similar constructs. Finally, all three subscales were able to distinguish problem from nonproblem children in that they explained between 10% and 31% of the variability in the presence of externalizing symptoms as measured by the CBCL-S and Spanish Conners-3. These findings are consistent with psychometric data reported for the English version of the DBD (Gerdes & Hoza, 2006).

sec.title: Cultural Properties
sec.p: In addition to establishing that the DBD-S is psychometrically sound, we also wanted to determine if its use with Spanish-speaking, Latino families was culturally appropriate. As partially predicted, one of the three ADHD subscales was significantly correlated with Anglo orientation, suggesting a possible cultural bias. Specifically, the Hyperactive-Impulsive subscale was positively correlated with Anglo orientation, suggesting that parents who were more acculturated endorsed more hyperactive-impulsive symptoms in their children. A trend toward significance in the same direction also emerged for the Total ADHD subscale. In contrast, none of the ADHD subscales were significantly related to Mexican orientation, which is consistent with our predictions.

Perhaps most interesting and as predicted, acculturation (i.e., neither Anglo nor Mexican orientation) was not significantly correlated with subscales of functional impairment (e.g., learning and peer problems) as measured by the Spanish Conners-3. The current results provide further support for initial findings suggesting that focusing on DSM-IV-TR symptomatology may not be as culturally sensitive as assessing for functional impairment associated with ADHD, particularly when examining hyperactive-impulsive symptoms (Arcia & Fernández, 1998; Bauermeister et al., 2005). Thus, the administration of a culturally appropriate and comprehensive measure of functional impairment across multiple domains, including academic, social, and familial, may be critical when assessing ADHD in Latino youth.

sec.title: Diagnostic Utility
sec.p: Although preliminary given the nature of the current sample, the results related to the diagnostic utility of the DBD-S are perhaps the most interesting. Based on the limited research available examining cultural differences in parental schemas for ADHD (Arcia & Fernández, 1998; Bauermeister et al., 2005), it was predicted that the inattentive and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms would not yield high diagnostic utility. Interestingly, this prediction was only supported when examining the hyperactive-impulsive symptoms. In general, the inattentive symptoms demonstrated moderately strong diagnostic utility for predicting both the presence and absence of ADHD. Two symptoms in particular (i.e., “often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly” and “often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities”) emerged as potential inclusion criteria given that the presence of these symptoms almost guaranteed a diagnosis of ADHD. An additional four inattentive symptoms (i.e., “often is easily distracted,” “often fails to give close attention to details,” “often has difficulty sustaining attention,” and “often loses things”) emerged as potential exclusion criteria, as the absence of these symptoms indicated a greater likelihood of the absence of ADHD.

Although the predictive power of the inattentive symptoms was better than expected, it is considerably lower than previous reports for predominately Caucasian samples. For example, in their examination of the diagnostic utility of the DSM-IV-TR ADHD symptoms in a clinical sample, Frick et al. (1994) reported a range of 0.55 to 0.78 and a mean of .69 (SD = 0.56) for the PPP of inattentive symptoms compared with a range of 0.31 to 1.00 and a mean of .51 (SD = 0.22) that emerged for the current sample. Similarly, Frick et al. reported a range of 0.59 to 0.97 with a mean of .76 (SD = 0.74) for the NPP of inattentive symptoms compared with a range of 0.14 to 0.63 and a mean of .49 (SD = 0.16) for the current sample.

The results for the hyperactive-impulsive symptoms were even more striking. With one exception for NPP (i.e., “often has difficulty awaiting turn”), the hyperactive-impulsive symptoms had much lower diagnostic utility than the inattentive symptoms in predicting both the presence and absence of ADHD in a community sample of Latino children. The predictive power of these symptoms is also much lower than that reported by Frick et al. (1994). Specifically, in the current sample, the PPP of hyperactive-impulsive symptoms ranged from 0.03 to 0.45 with a mean of .31 (SD = 0.17) compared with a range of 0.48 to 0.88 and a mean of .73 (SD = 0.52) for a predominately Caucasian sample. Similarly, the NPP of hyperactive-impulsive symptoms for the current sample ranged from 0.09 to 0.62 with a mean of .34 (SD = 0.17) relative to a range of 0.51 to 0.85 and a mean of .65 (SD = 0.51) for Frick et al.’s sample.

The generally low numbers that emerged for the NPP of these symptoms are particularly interesting, as they suggest that many Latino parents in the current sample view hyperactive-impulsive behaviors as developmentally normative. The failure of these symptoms to provide diagnostically useful information also is consistent with the acculturation findings that emerged in the current study, providing additional evidence that these symptoms may be culturally biased. Although these findings are preliminary and in need of replication with a clinical sample, they are consistent with the theoretical literature. Given the collectivist nature of Latino culture, it has been theorized that this particular worldview would likely be related to Latino parents being more accepting of their children’s behavior and less likely to identify externalizing behaviors, such as hyperactive-impulsive behaviors, as problematic (Schmitz & Velez, 2003). However, to our knowledge, the current findings provide the first empirical evidence to support the theoretical literature. Together, the acculturation and diagnostic utility findings also provide support for the argument that a culturally appropriate ADHD assessment must include a measure of functional impairment in addition to a measure of ADHD symptomatology, especially when the child is displaying hyperactive-impulsive symptoms. Interestingly, even in the context of working with Caucasian families, others also have argued that a measure of functional impairment in addition to a measure of symptomatology would likely improve our predictive power when diagnosing ADHD and is necessary for appropriate treatment planning and monitoring (Owens & Hoza, 2003; Pelham et al., 2005).

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Although the current study adds to our understanding of providing culturally appropriate assessments for childhood ADHD, several limitations could be improved on in future work. Our sample of Latino parents was rather homogeneous. In addition to being predominately female and of Mexican descent, more than half of the participants had a high school education or less and had a family income below the poverty level. In addition, less than a quarter of the participants reported that they were bilingual and more than a third of them reported that they spoke no English. Examining a more diverse Latino sample in terms of gender and subgroups, as well as socioeconomic status and acculturation, would provide additional insight into which Latino families would benefit the most from a more culturally sensitive assessment. Future work with a clinical sample examining concurrent teacher reports on the DBD-S, as well as the structured interview that accompanies the DBD (i.e., the DBD Structured Interview; Pelham, 2002), is also recommended, especially with regard to replicating the diagnostic utility findings. As discussed previously, based on research with predominately Caucasian families, Pelham et al. (2005) argued that a structured interview adds little diagnostic utility beyond parent- and teacher-rating scales; however, it may prove to be more useful with certain groups, such as less acculturated Latino families.

sec.title: Clinical Implications and Future Directions
sec.p: In closing, the current study has important clinical implications with regard to providing culturally appropriate assessments for ADHD and other childhood mental health disorders. Research documenting the disparity between need and utilization of mental health services for Latinos is clear, as is research providing recommendations for culturally appropriate assessments and interventions (Callejas et al., 2006; Flores et al., 2002; Garland et al., 2005; Hough et al., 2002; Kataoka et al., 2002; Rowland et al., 2002; Woods et al., 2005); however, much work remains. The current findings highlight the potential problems of translating already existing measures with the intent of providing a culturally sensitive assessment and the importance of examining not only the psychometric properties of these translated measures, but also the cultural properties and diagnostic utility when appropriate. Perhaps, most importantly, the current study provides further evidence that our overemphasis on DSM-IV-TR symptomatology may be particularly problematic when working with some Latino families, particularly those who are less acculturated (Arcia & Fernández, 1998; Bauermeister et al., 2005), and highlights the need for assessing parental acculturation as part of the ADHD assessment process when working with Latino families. Furthermore, although culturally appropriate measures of functional impairment in specific domains are beginning to emerge (Haack, Gerdes, Schneider, et al., 2011), a culturally appropriate and comprehensive measure of functional impairment tapping multiple domains related to childhood ADHD needs to be developed or an existing measure (e.g., the Weiss Functional Impairment Rating Scale–Parent Report; Weiss, 2010) needs to be translated and examined for its psychometric and cultural properties. We argue that the addition of such a measure to an ADHD assessment would improve the cultural appropriateness of the assessment and would allow for the examination of clinically meaningful change in impairment following treatment.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Alyson C. Gerdes is an associate professor at Marquette University. Her primary research interests include evidence-based assessment and treatment of childhood ADHD, culturally-appropriate clinical practices, and parenting and parent-child relationships in families of children with ADHD.

Kathryn E. Lawton is completing her Ph.D. in clinical psychology at Marquette University. Her research interests include culturally-appropriate assessment and treatment of childhood ADHD, as well as patterns of help-seeking in underserved populations.

Lauren M. Haack, M.S., graduated from Clemson University in 2007 with a B.A. in psychology and Spanish. She currently is a 5th year graduate student at Marquette University studying clinical psychology. Her primary research and clinical interests involve multicultural factors that influence the conceptualization, assessment, and treatment of ADHD in Latino children.

Gabriela Dieguez Hurtado is a bilingual therapist at the Sixteenth Street Community Health Center, providing services to the inner city population in Milwaukee, WI. She predominantly serves Latino clients with diverse mental health needs who are living below the poverty level. Her primary interest includes family relations, parenting, and depression.
